framework_notes.react: Use existing button/table/card components, consistent with TailwindCSS utilities

tasks.name: plan
tasks.title: Plan the next development task
what to do: Read .project/rules.md for standards. Read .project/ docs, README.md, TECHNICAL.md for context.
Use `make help` for commands. Use `uv run` for Python.
For CHPP/pychpp issues: Check pychpp/ folder (local git repo) - checkout matching version tag to verify API compatibility.
Follow quality gates in rules.md. Keep database backwards compatible.
Take a holistic view: Look for opportunities to consolidate, eliminate duplication, and reduce waste.
Structure: # Plan Next Task ## Analysis ## Solution ## Steps ## Challenges ## Testing
If the task is large, break it into smaller sub-tasks.
Simplify, reduce complexity, avoid over-engineering when planning. Challenge whether the task can be simplified further.
Do not add or commit code in this step.

tasks.name: execute
tasks.title: Execute the planned development task
what to do: Read .project/rules.md for standards. Read .project/ docs for context.
Use `uv run` for Python and `make help` for commands.
For CHPP/pychpp issues: Check pychpp/ folder (local git repo) - checkout matching version tag to verify API compatibility.
Follow the plan. Validate with `make test-all` - no coverage loss or test failures.
Take a holistic view: actively look for opportunities to simplify, consolidate, and eliminate waste.
If you see duplication, over-engineering, or unnecessary complexity, refactor to simplify.
Challenge existing solutions - can they be simplified without losing functionality?
Follow quality gates in rules.md. Keep database backwards compatible.
For UI work: Follow ui_guidelines in this file. Use consistent colors, typography, spacing.
Flask: Use .btn-primary-custom, .table-custom, .card-custom classes for consistency.
React: Use existing components with TailwindCSS utilities, maintain football theme.
Update docs per documentation-guide.md (backlog.md, progress.md, etc.).
Note any new tasks for backlog.md.
Do not add or commit code in this step.
If the task is large, break it into smaller sub-tasks and execute only one sub-task and keep the rest for the next time the execute task is run.

tasks.name: review
tasks.title: Review previous development work with simplification focus
what to do: Review not only the last task, but all the changes since the last commit.
Read .project/rules.md for standards. Read .project/ docs for context.
Take a holistic view: identify any introduced complexity, duplication, or waste.
Validate with `make test-all`, use `uv run` for Python.
Check docs updated per documentation-guide.md and strategic alignment per goals.md.
Look for consolidation opportunities - can the changes be simplified further?
Follow quality gates in rules.md. Keep database backwards compatible.
Add new tasks to backlog.md, focusing on simplification and waste reduction.
Do not add or commit code in this step.

tasks.name: update
tasks.title: Update project status and planning
what to do: Review progress.md and backlog.md current state with a holistic view for simplification.
Update both files with completed tasks and metrics. Look for opportunities to consolidate similar tasks.
Remove completed tasks (marked ✅) from backlog.md - move them to history/backlog-done.md with completion notes.
Eliminate redundant or obsolete tasks. Merge overlapping work to reduce complexity.
Unblock dependencies, move ready tasks to active status.
When updating docs (README.md, .project/*, TECHNICAL.md, DEPLOYMENT.md, docs/*), ensure they describe the current architecture and decisions.
Aggressively remove or compress outdated information and redundant content to reduce cognitive load.
Do not add or commit code in this step.

tasks.name: commit
tasks.title: Create commits for changes since last commit following git guidelines
what to do: Analyze changes and additions since last commit. Group related changes logically.
Write factual commit messages: <50 char subject, body: imperative mood, no fluff, refer to issues if possible.
Stage and commit. Don't push.

tasks.name: add-to-backlog
tasks.title: Add a new task to the project backlog with simplification focus
what to do: Read .project/rules.md for standards. Read .project/ docs for context.
Take a holistic view: check if this task duplicates existing work or can be consolidated.
Analyze task alignment with goals.md and dependencies. Challenge if task can be simplified.
Look for opportunities to merge with existing tasks to reduce backlog complexity.
Add to backlog.md with priority and category recommendation. Both in the Current Focus and Detailed Backlog sections.

tasks.name: execute-backlog-item
tasks.title: Plan and execute a specific backlog item with simplification focus
what to do: Focus on the specified backlog item. Read .project/rules.md for standards.
Read .project/ docs for context. Take a holistic view to identify simplification opportunities.
Before executing, challenge if the task can be simplified or consolidated with other work.
Create implementation plan, execute step by step. Use `uv run` for Python.
Look for opportunities to eliminate duplication and reduce complexity during execution.
Test against acceptance criteria per rules.md. Update docs per documentation-guide.md.
Mark completed in backlog.md.
Structure: # Execution: [TASK-ID] ## Overview ## Plan ## Steps ## Validation ## Summary

tasks.name: analyze-project
tasks.title: Repository analysis for simplification and complexity reduction
what to do: Use list_dir and file_search to analyze repository structure with focus on simplification.
Take a holistic view: identify duplication, waste, over-engineered solutions, and unnecessary complexity.
Review all docs (README.md, .project/*, TECHNICAL.md, DEPLOYMENT.md, docs/*) for redundancy and outdated content.
Find opportunities to consolidate, merge, or eliminate redundant components and processes.
Create backlog tasks for: simplification, deduplication, waste reduction, complexity reduction.
Structure: # Analysis ## Simplification Opportunities ## Duplication & Waste ## Complexity Reduction ## Actions

tasks.name: organize-backlog
tasks.title: Organize and clean up project backlog with simplification focus
what to do: Read .project/ docs for context. Take a holistic view of the backlog for simplification opportunities.
Identify and consolidate duplicate or overlapping tasks - merge similar work to reduce complexity.
Remove obsolete tasks, eliminate waste, and challenge whether complex tasks can be simplified.
Look for patterns: Can multiple small tasks be combined? Can over-engineered solutions be simplified?
Fix dependencies and priorities with focus on reducing cognitive load and decision complexity.
Keep rules at top, details at bottom, use markdown links for navigation.

tasks.name: look-outside-the-box
tasks.title: Generate innovative opportunities
what to do: First, scan plan.md, progress.md, backlog.md, and 'Future Opportunities' in plan.md for existing suggestions.
Think step-by-step like an innovative strategist: Analyze project docs, code structure, and current capabilities.
**Simplification Challenge**: Question complexity - what if we eliminated 50% of features? What's the simplest viable approach?

**Black Hat Challenge**: Play devil's advocate. Question 2-3 fundamental decisions (tech stack, architecture, goals). Ask: 'What if this core choice is wrong? What single change would collapse the project—and how could we pivot profitably?'

Use these techniques: (1) Contrarian questions ('What if we did the opposite?'); (2) Analogies from unrelated industries ('How would Netflix approach this?'); (3) Brainstorm 8-10 wild ideas first, then refine to 2-5 high-impact ones; (4) Radical simplification ('What's the absolute minimum viable approach?').
For each opportunity, provide: clear value proposition, why it's novel, and how it expands or pivots the project.
Add only new, high-value suggestions to 'Future Opportunities' section in plan.md (not backlog).
Structure: # Innovation ## Step-by-Step Assessment ## Black Hat Challenge ## Wild Ideas Brainstorm ## Refined Opportunities ## Value Summary ## Added to plan.md
